predicted_summary: Directs the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) make an injury determination in an antidumping or countervailing duty investigation initiated under this Act; or (2) determine whether an industry in the United States is being threatened with material injury. Authorizes a civil action in a United States district court.Directs the Commission to make a determination within 30 days after an initial investigation that resulted in an antidumping or countervailing duty order being terminated or suspended, and to issue a final determination within 60 days after the initial review.Directs the Commission to conduct an investigation and compile evidence with respect to the petition in the same manner and to the same extent as if an election had not been made.Requires an order issued by the International Trade Commission (ITC) to be appealed to a united States court of appeals. (Sec. 3) Sets forth precedential effect requirements for such proceedings.Sets forth certain procedural requirements for a civil action against a defendant.Directs the Commission to make a final determination within 45 days after a complaint has been filed regarding material injury, or the establishment of an industry in the united states is materially retarded, by reason of imports of the subject merchandise and that imports of such merchandise are not negligible.Requires the court to make a final determination regarding the likelihood of continuation or recurrence of material injury under this Act before the later of the calendar year.Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to: (1) require a court to issue an injury determination within 30 days after the date on which the injury determination was first made; and (2) allow a jury to determine the award of a criminal penalty. (3) In the case of a party seeking revocation of an order or termination of a suspended investigation, the court shall seek review in the district court that made the original injury determination.Directs the Secretary of Commerce to: (1) notify the appropriate U.S. Trade Representative of the proposed remedies, antidumping duty investigations, antiduty investigations, countervailing duty reviews, and other measures applicable to goods from Argentina and Mexico on or after the date of the enactment of this Act; (2) report to the appropriate United States district court with respect to goods imported from Argentina or Mexico on such date; and (3) advise the appropriate International Trade Organization (ITO) of the amendments made by this Act.
summary:
Unfair Foreign Competition Act of 2007 - Amends the Tariff Act of 1930 to authorize a petitioning party, in an antidumping or countervailing duty investigation, to elect, within 30 days after the investigation has started, to bring a civil action in a U.S. district court for determination that a U.S. industry is materially injured or is threatened with material injury, or the establishment of an industry in the United States is materially retarded, by reason of imports, or sales (or the likelihood of sales) for importation, of the merchandise subject to the investigation, and that imports of the subject merchandise are not negligible.

Authorizes such a petitioning party, within 30 days after a five-year review of an antidumping or countervailing duty order is initiated, to bring a civil action in a U.S. district court for determination of whether revocation of the antidumping or countervailing duty order, or termination of a suspended investigation, would likely lead to continuation or recurrence of material injury.

Provides for preliminary relief and expedited action.

Applies this Act to goods from Canada and Mexico.

predicted_summary: Substance Abuse Prevention and Treatment Enhancement Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to establish designated programs for the prevention and treatment of substance abuse.Designates an award recipient and recipient of federal financial assistance under a designated program.Voucherized Assistance Programs (EDAP) are programs in which the beneficiary is given a document or other authorization that may be used to pay for program services. Programs are programs that provide counseling, substance abuse, or preventive services regarding such abuse under specified circumstances.Prohibits the designation of any public or private entity as a program participant or subaward recipient regardless of whether the entity provides program services or not. Allows religious organizations to be program participants on the same basis as any other nonprofit private provider without impairing the religious character of such organizations or religious organizations.Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to: (1) make religious organizations eligible to be program participants on the basis of their religious character and freedom; and (2) ensure that such organizations retain their independence from federal, state, and local government (local government) and control over the definition, development, practice, and expression of such religious beliefs.Requires religious organizations to:  (1) alter its organizational structure; (2) remove religious art, icons, scripture, or other symbols; and (3) make such organization's religious beliefs and practices subject to applicable federal or State law or regulation.Requires an alternative entity to arrange for the individual to receive program services through an alternative provider.Requires a program beneficiary to: (1) participate actively in religious practice, worship, and instruction; and (2) follow rules of behavior devised by the organizations that are religious in content or origin.Directs the use of such funds for religious purposes only if the beneficiary is a program participant or a program beneficiary of a specified program.Prohibits state or local governments from imposing religious educational qualification requirements on providers of drug treatment programs, including religious organizations, in order to ensure the effectiveness of such programs.Directs the Secretary to waive any educational qualification imposed on an individual religious organization if: (1) the religious organization has failed to demonstrate empirically that the educational qualifications are necessary to the successful operation of a drug treatment program; and (2) the state or local government has not demonstrated empirically, that such qualification is necessary to a program's successful operation.
summary:
Faith-Based Drug Treatment Enhancement Act - Amends the Public Health Service Act to declare that the amendments made by this Act apply to each program that makes awards of Federal financial assistance to prevent or treat substance abuse. 
Allows, notwithstanding any other provision of law, a religious organization to be an award recipient, make subawards, provide services through vouchers, or accept vouchers for providing services. Makes religious organizations eligible on the same basis as any other nonprofit private organization.  Prohibits Federal or State: (1) discrimination against an organization on the basis that the organization has a religious character; and (2) requirements that a religious organization, in order to be a program participant, remove religious art, icons, scripture, or other symbols. 
Requires a religious organization to arrange for services through an alternative entity if an individual objects to the religious organization.  Allows a religious organization to require a beneficiary who has elected to receive services from the organization to actively participate in religious practice, worship, and instruction. 
Prohibits using funds for sectarian worship or instruction, unless the beneficiary may choose where the assistance is redeemed or allocated. 
Declares that assistance to or on behalf of a beneficiary is aid to the beneficiary and not to the organization.  Requires, if a State law or constitution would prevent the expenditure of State or local funds by religious organizations, that the Federal funds shall be segregated from State or other public funds. 
Requires, for personnel working in religious organization drug treatment programs, giving credit for religious education and training equivalent to credit given for secular course work.  Mandates waiver of educational requirements if the religious organization has a record of successful drug treatment and the State or local government fails to demonstrate empirically that the educational qualifications are necessary.

predicted_summary: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the federal retail excise tax on new heavy trucks, tractors, and trailers. Requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress on:  (1) the cost of new heavy-duty trucks and tractors and trailers in 2016 and 2017, and (2) the average retail price for such trucks and trailers is $175,921; (3) the Federal Retail excise tax is the highest percentage rate in the history of the tax.Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) final rules establishing the phase 2 emissions standards for medium and heavy-duty engines and vehicles, and final rulemaking to establish the fuel economy standards for them, will add up to approximately $12,000 to the price of new heavy- duty trucks; and (1) in addition to the additional federal excise tax on new heavy trucks, tractors, and trailers, the Department of Transportation (DOT) will add $6,683 to the average price of a new heavy duty truck.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the excise tax on heavy trucks and trailers.Amends the Federal Emergency Management Act of 1933 to: (1) allow the use of such vehicles for the operation of construction, manufacturing, processing, farming, mining, drilling, timbering, or similar operation only if the operation is unrelated to transportation on or off the public highways; and (2) require such vehicles to be maintained in good repair and maintained by the Federal Highway Administration (FHSA) for at least 30 days.Amends the Internal Revenue Code to: (1) make sales and installations free of tax under this Act; and (2) make such sales and installation subject to tax. (Sec. 3) repeal the prohibition against sale, purchase, or installation of any item that is not expressly prohibited by this Act.
summary: Heavy Truck, Tractor, and Trailer Retail Federal Excise Tax Repeal Act of 2017  This bill amends the Internal Revenue Code to repeal the 12% excise tax on the retail sale of heavy trucks and trailers.

predicted_summary: Requires the Secretary of the Interior to enter into an agreement with the Pueblo to settle all claims that were raised or could have been raised against the United States under the isleta jurisdictional act.Directs the Secretary of the Interior to enter into a settlement agreement with the Pueblo of Isleta, pursuant to which the Secretary shall administer the Fund.Requires the Secretary to distribute funds from the Fund to the Pueblo upon request of the pueblo, at such times and in such amounts as are specified for that purpose in the annual budget of the Department of the Interior.Directs the Secretary to distribute funds to the Pueblo for drainage and remediation expenses.Requires the Secretary of the Interior to coordinate and coordinate the restoration work. Provides that funds, including interest income, be used to carry out such work.Requires that the Pueblo, upon receipt and use of funds from the restoration fund, make no provision regarding expenditures and withdrawals.Requires the Secretary of the Treasury, upon receipt of an amended tribal management plan, to ensure that any funds in the restoration fund are used in accordance with this Act.Requires the Secretary of the Interior to approve the extension plan if the plan is reasonable and consistent with this Act and the settlement agreement.Prohibits the Secretary of the Interior from interfering in the determination of the final judgment in the case of Pueblo of isleta v. United States in the United States Court of Federal Claims.Directs the Secretary of the Interior, upon request from the Secretary, to provide for the removal of ordnance by specified means.
summary:
Pueblo of Isleta Settlement and Natural Resources Restoration Act of 2006 - Establishes in the Treasury the Pueblo of Isleta Natural Resources Restoration Fund for: (1) settlement of the claims of the Pueblo of Isleta; and (2) the acquisition, restoration, improvement, development, and protection of land, natural resources, and cultural resources within the exterior boundaries of the Pueblo. Provides for the maintenance and investment of the restoration fund.

Ratifies the Agreement of Compromise and Settlement entered into between the United States and the Pueblo on July 12, 2005, as modified by the Extension and Modification Agreement executed by the United States and the Pueblo on June 22, 2006, to settle the claims in the case of Pueblo of Isleta v. United States, Docket No. 98-166L, pending in the U.S. Court of Federal Claims.

Directs the Pueblo and the United States to execute and file a joint stipulation for entry of final judgment in dismissal of such case.

Provides for the payment of compensation to the Pueblo from the permanent judgment appropriation for all monetary damages and attorney fees, interest, and other fees and costs of any kind that were or could have been presented in connection with Docket No. 98-166L.

predicted_summary: Requires the Administrator to develop and carry out a pilot program to serve as a national model for the restoration of urban watersheds and community environments.Requires the Administrator to:  (1) coordinate the restoration and protection efforts with other Federal, State, and local government programs and provide community involvement in the decisionmaking process; (2) assist in the establishment of measurable goals for such restoration; and (3) maintain annual program plans which provide for public input in the development of measurable environmental conditions.Directs the Administrator to:  (1) establish on-the-ground projects for restoration of the watershed to the extent they are unique or transferable to national audiences; and (2) maintain and enhance the biennial work plan for the anacostia river watershed. Directs Federal landholders, tribal governments, and the Environmental Protection Agency to participate in urban habitat improvement projects in the watershed on a demonstration basis.Requires the Administrator to work in coordination with other Federal agencies, particularly the Army Corps of Engineers, to identify projects and activities which are supportive of the goals of the pilot program.
summary:
Authorizes the Administrator to set aside amounts for grants to local community groups and nonprofit organizations to foster community involvement in the decision making process, environmental educational goals, and restoration strategies.
Authorizes appropriations.
